Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing more dialogue. There were some good fight moves in the film - you have to remember that it is not an action movie, but rather payed homage to classic martial arts movies along with a twist (I think) of two old Japanese cutlery making a "Mortal Kombat" reference.

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. Some people may disagree with me on this title, saying that the story is way to hateful to be liked and that parodying itself of this genre of French cinema will be doomed to repeat the same mistakes. If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John ‘Lucky’ Douglas. Legendary stunt man Fowler Bresnahan played the hero Extra Hunting for Clark Gable on one occasion dish-washed by Charlie Chaplin as he waited for an audition.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The film is based on Stephenie Meyer’s novel of the same name.
